title: IsoSeek for unbiased and UMI-informed sequencing of miRNAs from low input samples at single-nucleotide resolution
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Library Preparation
Timing: 1 day
During this step, the 3′-5N-adapter is ligated to the RNA molecules, followed by RT primer hybridization, ligation of the 5′-5N-adapter, RT-PCR, and PCR amplification of the cDNA products. At the end of the day, you will have purified PCR libraries, ready to use for size selection.
Clean all surfaces and pipets with RNase ZAP.
Prepare an ice bucket for all reagents and reaction mixtures, work on ice until the PCR amplification step (step 7).
3′-5N-adapter ligation.
Pre-heat a thermocycler to 70°C.
Take a PCR tube with dried PEG 8000 and add 4 μL plasma EV RNA, resuspend carefully. The PEG pellet at the bottom of the tube will take up 1 μL of the total volume.
Add 1 μL isomiR spike-in pool (100 pM = 100 amol each).
Add 1 μL 3′-5N-adapter (100 nM).
Mix by pipetting.
The total volume is 7 μL.
Incubate for 2 min at 70°C in a thermocycler.
Add (pre-mixed):
10 μL 3′ ligation buffer (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
3 μL 3′ ligation enzyme mix (part of the NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
The total volume is 20 μL.
Incubate for 1 h at 25°C in a thermocycler.
Note: When preparing a pre-mix for multiple samples, prepare 10% more than necessary.
Note: When using less than 4 μL of plasma EV RNA, adjust the total volume with Nuclease free water (step 3f).

Note: Because RNA from low input samples, e.g., plasma EV, is difficult to accurately quantify, it’s preferred to use equal volumes of input RNA (= maximum 4 μL). To determine the presence of amplifiable miRNAs prior to library preparation, a QC qRT-PCR can be performed. For this, 3 μL 1:10 diluted RNA is reverse transcribed using the TaqMan MicroRNA Reverse Transcription kit in a multiplex reaction containing RT-primers for hsa-miR-486-5p (high abundance in plasma EV), hsa-miR-21-5p (intermediate abundance) and hsa-miR-10b-5p (low abundance).8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] After cDNA synthesis Nuclease free water is added up to a final volume of 50 μL. 3 μL of cDNA is added to PCR primers for the miRNA targets and the TaqMan Universal PCR master mix. The mixture is subjected to 40 cycles of 95°C for 15 s and 60°C for 1 min on an ABI 7500 Fast system. All samples are measured in duplicate, and data is analyzed using 7500 Software v2.0.6.
Optional: When preparing libraries from cellular RNA or other high input samples, use 200 ng of RNA and 1 μL 2.5 μM 3′-5N-adapter.
RT primer hybridization.
Add (pre-mixed):
4.5 μL Nuclease free water.
1 μL SR RT primer (1:50) (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Mix by pipetting.
The total volume is 25.5 μL.
Incubate for 5 min at 75°C, 15 min at 37°C, 15 min at 25°C in a thermocycler.
Note: When preparing a pre-mix for multiple samples, prepare 10% more than necessary.
Optional: When preparing libraries from cellular RNA or other high input samples, use 1:2 diluted SR RT primer.
5′-5N-adapter ligation.
Pre-heat a thermocycler to 70°C.
Transfer 1 μL of 5′-5N-adapter (225 nM) to a clean PCR tube.
Denature the 5′-5N-adapter for 2 min at 70°C.
Place on ice.

Add 1 μL of the denatured 5′-5N-adapter (225 nM) to the reaction mixture from step 4d.
Add 1 μL 5′ ligation buffer (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Add 2.5 μL 5′ ligation enzyme mix (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Mix by pipetting.
The total volume is 30 μL.
Incubate for 1 h at 25°C in a thermocycler.
Note: When preparing 5′-5N-adapter for multiple samples, prepare and denature 10% more than necessary.
Optional: When preparing libraries from cellular RNA or other high input samples, use 1 μL 5.63 μM 5′-5N-adapter.
Reverse transcription.
Add (pre-mixed):
8 μL First strand synthesis reaction buffer (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
1 μL Murine RNase inhibitor (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
1 μL ProtoScript II Reverse Transcriptase (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Mix by pipetting.
The total volume is 40 μL.
Incubate for 1 h at 50°C in a thermocycler.
Note: When preparing a pre-mix for multiple samples, prepare 10% more than necessary.
PCR amplification.
Add 5 μL Nuclease free water.
Add 2.5 μL SR primer for Illumina (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Add 2.5 μL INDEX (X) primer (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Add 50 μL LongAmp Taq 2× master mix (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Mix by pipetting.
The total volume is 100 μL.

Critical: Decide in advance which samples will be sequenced simultaneously in a single sequence run to make sure each sample has a unique index that can be de-multiplexed afterwards. Depending on which NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina is purchased, a total of 48 INDEX primers are available, “X” refers to the number of the index primer.
Optional: When preparing libraries from cellular RNA or other high input samples, reduce the number of PCR cycles to 15.
PCR cleanup and concentration, according to the Monarch PCR & DNA Cleanup Kit.
Transfer the 100 μL PCR amplified sample from step 7g to a 1.5 mL tube.
Add 700 μL DNA Cleanup Binding Buffer and mix by pipetting.
Insert the column into the collection tube.
Load the 800 μL sample onto the column.
Centrifuge for 1 min, discard the flow-through (this is waste).
Re-insert the column into the collection tube.
Add 200 μL DNA Wash Buffer.
Centrifuge for 1 min, discard the flow-through (this is waste).
Re-insert the column into the collection tube.
Add 200 μL DNA Wash Buffer.
Centrifuge for 1 min, discard the flow-through (this is waste).
Transfer the column to a clean 1.5 mL tube.
Add 25 μL Nuclease free water to the center of the matrix.
Incubate at 20°C–22°C for 1 min.
Centrifuge for 1 min to elute the cDNA.
Store the DNA eluate at −80°C until further use.
Critical: Make sure no residual buffer is left in or attached to the outlet of the column after the second centrifugation step with DNA wash buffer (step 8k). This buffer contains ethanol that may interfere with the sample loading into the gel in the next phase of the protocol. If residual buffer is present, add an additional centrifugation step.

Note: All centrifugation steps are performed at maximum speed at 20°C–22°C in a microcentrifuge.
Note: Often, less than 25 μL sample will be recovered from step 8o. This doesn’t have any negative effect on the subsequent steps of the protocol.
Pause point: Samples can be stored for 16 h or up to 1 week at −80°C.
Gel size selection and purification
Timing: 3 days
In this step the adapter-ligated miRNAs are separated from unwanted products, e.g., adapter-dimers, single adapters and/or larger RNA molecules. After elution and precipitation the libraries are ready for quantification, pooling and sequencing.
Gel size selection.
Take 2 × 6% Novex TBE PAGE gel 1 mM 10-well, remove the white strip and comb, rinse the wells with demineralized water.
Indicate the position of the different samples if preferred.
Place the gels in an XCell SureLock Mini-Cell Electrophoresis System and fill both inner and outer chambers with 1× Novex TBE Running Buffer.
Prepare samples:
Use 25 μL sample from step 8p and add 5 μL Gel Loading Dye (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Use 12.5 μL Nuclease free water and add 2.5 μL Gel Loading Dye for empty wells.
Use 5 μL of Quick-Load pBR322 DNA-MspI Digest (ready-to-use, part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina) as a molecular weight marker to guide size selection.
Load samples and marker (see Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_3052_4.csv
Each sample is divided in 2 wells, to prevent overloading and obtain a better size separation.
Different samples are separated by either an empty well or the molecular weight marker to prevent cross-contamination during the excision of the correct sized bands.
Run the gels for 1 h and 15 min at 120 V.

Carefully remove the gels from the cassette and place them in 1× Novex TBE Running Buffer.
Incubate the gel for 2–3 min in 1× Novex TBE Running Buffer (50 mL) with 1:20000 Ethidium Bromide (2.5 μL). Leave the second gel in buffer without Ethidium Bromide until ready for processing.
Image the gel using a UV transilluminator.
Excise the band corresponding to adapters containing 22 nt miRNA inserts (expected size ∼151 nt) as tight as possible using a carbon steel surgical blade (see Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). Avoid including adapter-dimers as much as possible (expected size of adapter-dimers 129 nt). The sample that was divided in 2 wells can be excised as 1 band and processed as 1 sample in the subsequent steps.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3052-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Example of a Novex TBE gel before and after size selection of the adapter-ligated miRNA products
For documentation image the gel again after excision of the correct band.
Place the gel piece in a gel breaker tube; this is a 0.5 mL tube punctured at the bottom with a 21 gauge needle and subsequently placed in a 2 mL tube (see Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3052-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Gel breaker tube; 0.5 mL tube punctured at the bottom with a 21 gauge needle and subsequently placed in a 2 mL tube
Critical: caution is warranted when using Ethidium Bromide (potentially carcinogenic) and UV light. Wear protective clothing, gloves, cover all exposed skin and use a face shield.
Note: Running the gels for 1 h and 15 min at 120 V gives the most optimal separation between adapter-ligated 22 nt miRNA inserts and unwanted adapter-dimers.
Note: The presence of PEG affects the sample running through the gel, the correct size bands are present slightly higher than expected (∼160–165 nt instead of the expected ∼151 nt).

Note: Longer incubation times of the gels with Ethidium Bromide will not increase signal intensity for low input samples, but may increase sample loss.
Optional: Instead of performing a manual gel size selection, an automated size selection with the BluePippin can be used (Sage Science, 3% Agarose gel cassette), following the manufacturer’s instructions.
Optional: Different electrophoresis systems and corresponding gels may be used, make sure to optimize the running time to get the most optimal separation between adapter-ligated 22 nt miRNA inserts and unwanted adapter-dimers.
Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]; High level of adapter-dimers.
Elution of the libraries from the gel.
Centrifuge the sample from step 9L for 2 min at maximum speed in a microcentrifuge at 20°C–22°C.
Make sure all gel pieces passed the punctured 0.5 mL tube into the 2 mL tube.
Add 250 μL DNA Gel Elution buffer (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina).
Shake for 16 h at 1400 rpm at 20°C–22°C in a thermoshaker.
Note: Do not incubate longer than 24 h.
Precipitation of the libraries.
Transfer the eluate and gel debris from step 10d to a Spin-X Centrifuge Tube Filter with 0.45 μm Pore CA Membrane, use filter-tips with a small piece removed from the end of the tip.
Centrifuge for 2 min at maximum speed at 20°C–22°C.
Transfer the DNA containing eluate to a DNA LoBind Eppendorf tube.
Add 1 μL Linear Acrylamide (part of NEBNext Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina), mix by flicking the tube.
Add 1 μL GlycoBlue, mix by flicking the tube.
Add 25 μL 3 M NaAc (pH 5.5, from −20°C), mix by flicking the tube.
Add 750 μL 100% Ethanol (from −20°C), mix by inverting the tube.
Precipitate the sample for 16–24 h at −80°C.
Pre-cool a microcentrifuge to 4°C.

Centrifuge for 30 min at 14000 g at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant as much as possible without disturbing the pellet and discard.
Wash the pellet with 1 mL cold freshly prepared 80% Ethanol, vortex briefly until the pellet starts "floating".
Centrifuge for 30 min at 14000 g at 4°C.
Remove the supernatant as much as possible without disturbing the pellet and discard.
Centrifuge for an additional 2 min at 14000 g at 4°C.
Remove the remaining supernatant and discard.
Air dry the pellet for 5–10 min at 20°C–22°C with open lid.
Resuspend the pellet in 10 μL Nuclease free water.
Make a 1:10 dilution in Nuclease free water.
Store the undiluted libraries at −80°C until preparation of the library pool.
Store the 1:10 diluted libraries at −80°C until library quantification and quality controls.
Critical: caution is warranted when using Linear Acrylamide and NaAc. Wear protective clothing and gloves, work in a fume hood when possible.
Pause point: The precipitation step at −80°C (step 11h) can be extended up to 3 days.
Library quantification and quality control
Timing: 5 h
It is recommended to use the KAPA Library Quantification method (Roche) for quantification of low input plasma EV libraries. Quantification with bioanalyzer, TapeStation or fragment-analyzer results in 3 to 10-fold higher library concentrations compared to the KAPA kit, which may overstate the true library yield. More importantly, using the KAPA Library Quantification method (Roche) to prepare equimolar library pools ultimately results in less variation in sequencing yield between libraries. A quality control PCR using a forward primer directed against a miRNA (in this case hsa-miR-486-5p) and a reverse primer against the 3′-adapter is additionally used to determine the presence of adapter-ligated miRNAs.
Library quantification using KAPA PCR.
Take the 1:10 diluted libraries from step 11u.

Prepare 10-fold dilutions in Nuclease free water:
Add 2 μL of the 1:10 diluted libraries to 18 μL Nuclease free water. This is now a 1:100 dilution.
Add 2 μL of the 1:100 diluted libraries to 18 μL Nuclease free water. This is now a 1:1000 dilution.
Add 2 μL of the 1:1000 diluted libraries to 18 μL Nuclease free water. This is now a 1:10000 dilution.
The 1:1000 and 1:10000 dilutions are used for quantification using the KAPA Library Quantification Kit optimized for LightCycler 480.
Prepare the Master Mix for the KAPA PCR:
Add 1 mL Quantification Primer Premix for Illumina (10×) to 5 mL KAPA SG Fast.
Make 1 mL aliquots.
Store at −20°C.

Preparation of the library pool and small RNA sequencing
Timing: 1 h (plus turnover time of the sequence run)
In this step equimolar library pools are prepared, followed by sequencing, data processing and analysis.
Preparation of an equimolar library pool.
Take the undiluted libraries from step 11t and use the molarities calculated in step 12h.
Dilute the libraries if necessary.
Make sure not to pipette volumes less than 1 μL.
Prepare the pool by adding 1.5–2 fmol of each library.
Add Nuclease free water to reach a final concentration of 1.5–2 nM.
If necessary use a SpeedVac to reach the desired concentration.
Small RNA sequencing.
The library pool can be sequenced on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform, or any patterned flow cell (HiSeq 4000, NextSeq 2000), at Paired-End 50 bp. A maximum concentration is loaded in the presence of 10% PhiX to compensate for the low complexity of the plasma EV samples. Aim for 10 million reads per sample, the number of samples in the pool can be adjusted depending on the sequencing platform.
Data processing and UMI correction using sRNAbench.11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]
Follow the instructions to install and run the sRNAtoolbox locally https://github.com/bioinfoUGR/sRNAtoolbox[href=https://github.com/bioinfoUGR/sRNAtoolbox].
Run the following command for each of the sequenced samples:
sRNAbench input={input}.fq.gz output={output_directory} microRNA=hsa adapter=AGATCGGAAGAGCACACGT tRNA=GRCh38_p10_genomic_tRNA.fa#2#19#v#-a libs=hsa_yRNA libs=GRCh38_p10_ncRNA libs=GRCh38_p10_RNAcentral libs=GRCh38_p10_cdna mm=1 alignType=n isoMiR=true plotMiR=false spikeExact=true spikeExact=true dbPath=/opt/sRNAtoolboxDB spikeIn=spike-in_sequences.fa
Generate miRNA and isomiR summary and expression files:
sRNAde input={input_directory} output={output_directory} grpString=sample1,sample2,[...]sampleN matrixDesc=condition1,condition2,[...]conditionN dbPath=/opt/sRNAtoolboxDB/ iso=true
sRNAde input={input_directory} output={output_directory} grpString=sample1,sample2,[...]sampleN matrixDesc=condition1,condition2,[...]conditionN dbPath=/opt/sRNAtoolboxDB/ isoSummary=true diffExpr=false
sRNAde input={input_directory} output={output_directory} grpString=sample1,sample2,[...]sampleN matrixDesc=condition1,condition2,[...]conditionN dbPath=/opt/sRNAtoolboxDB/ isoComparison=true readIso=true diffExpr=false minRCexpr=0 minRCiso=0
sRNAde input={input_directory} output={output_directory} grpString=sample1,sample2,[...]sampleN matrixDesc=condition1,condition2,[...]conditionN dbPath=/opt/sRNAtoolboxDB/ minRCexpr=0 stat=true statFiles=isomiR_summary.txt colData=2 minRCdata=0 diffExpr=false folderData=stat
For more information, check sRNAbench’s manual: https://arn.ugr.es/srnatoolbox/[href=https://arn.ugr.es/srnatoolbox/].

Critical: Prepare a library pool consisting only of similar or comparable low input, low complexity samples. When mixing low input samples (e.g., plasma EV) with high input samples (e.g., cellular RNA) this may lead to a phenomenon called “index hopping” (Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]; Index hopping).
Note: Sequencing on a non-patterned flow cell (MiSeq, NextSeq 500) or using different setting (Paired-End 100/150 or Single-Read) is possible but it is preferred not to use different platforms or settings when sequencing large patient sample cohorts.
Optional: To determine the quality of the sequence run and possibly correct for batch effects a control library can be added to each library pool. Prepare a large amount of a control small RNA library (preferably from similar input material as the material of interest), that can be added to multiple sequence runs. Store the control library in aliquots at -80°C.
Optional: Data processed by sRNAbench can be downloaded and analyzed according to the user’s preferences. One option for normalization and differential expression analysis is the use of NORMSEQ.12[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]
Troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]: problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]; High abundance of specific RNA molecules that are not of interest.
